title: 449-D
statement: D. Jzzhu and Numberstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutJzzhu havennon-negative integersa1,a2, ...,an. We will call a sequence of indexesi1,i2, ...,ik(1 ≤i1<i2< ... <ik≤n)a group of sizek.Jzzhu wonders, how many groups exists such thatai1&ai2& ... &aik= 0(1 ≤k≤n)? Help him and print this number modulo1000000007(109+ 7). Operationx&ydenotes bitwise AND operation of two numbers.InputThe first line contains a single integern(1 ≤n≤ 106). The second line containsnintegersa1,a2, ...,an(0 ≤ai≤ 106).OutputOutput a single integer representing the number of required groups modulo1000000007(109+ 7).ExamplesInput32 3 3Output0Input40 1 2 3Output10Input65 2 0 5 2 1Output53

processed.result:
You are given a sequence of non-negative integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$.  

Find the number of groups of integers you can form from this sequence, where a group is defined as a subsequence of integers $a_{i_1}, a_{i_2}, ..., a_{i_k}$ (where $1 \le i_1 < i_2 < ... < i_k \le n$).

The number of groups should be calculated based on the following condition: the bitwise AND of all integers in each group must equal 0 ($a_{i_1} & a_{i_2} & ... & a_{i_k} = 0$).

Output the number of such groups modulo 1000000007 ($10^9 + 7$).

Given a list of numbers, count how many groups of numbers you can make where the bitwise AND of all the numbers in each group is zero.  The group size can be any number from 1 to the length of the list.  The answer should be the count modulo 1000000007.
